text:
Research shows that
living in the midst
of high-conflict relationships
can actually damage your health,

shorten your life span and can
even make your brain age faster.

So, how can you fix a relationship
when it's going wrong?
Talking about it at an early stage,

but talking about it
when you're calm.

So actually setting
aside some time

where you're not
going to have distractions
and you can talk to the other person

but in just quite
a neutral, pragmatic

'how are we going to sort this out?'
kind of a way.

I think the longer
you try and bottle it up

the more it comes out as a
snippy comment here and there.

If something's wrong
or something annoys you,
bring it up sooner rather than later.

If there are difficulties around
your sex life remember this -

in a committed
monogamous relationship

you're the only other person
who can give that to your partner.

So it's really imperative that you
do both find a happy medium
that satisfies both of you.

The couples that have been
together for a longer period,

they talked about the fact
that the relationship
is just not as passionate as it was,

but that wasn’t
an issue for them.

So the people who
had a good sex life,

it seemed to be like
an added bonus.

They were strongly attracted
to each other,
sex was a good connection for them,
but it was an additional benefit

on top of the friendship
and the companionship.

Be honest with each other about
what you need in the bedroom,

be proactive and really
take your time to work at it,
because it may not happen overnight

but you do want to reach a point
where you're both satisfied.

Do we actually have a good friendship
that's going to last the course?

It's not just that
I'm attracted to this person,
but actually we have enough in common
that in 30, 40 years' time,

if we've had kids
and they've left home,

we're still going to enjoy
each other's company.
I think...

we definitely have
a foundation of friendship.

We mostly hang
out with each other

so if you didn’t like spending
time with each other it's probably...
That would be a bit rubbish.
I'd say you're my best friend.

The longer you're
going out with someone,

the more of a confidante
they become,

and the more you open up about
things you wouldn't even open up to
your best mates about.
Yeah.
What was the question?

One lady told me 'well I wasn't
expecting it to be Cinderella'
and 'roses every day'
and so they weren’t disappointed

because their expectations were
quite realistic in the first place.

We had to decide very quickly ,
because I'm from an Indian family,

they didn’t necessarily approve
of me dating a white person.

It's all fine now,
it did mean we had to decide

very early on how committed
we were because it's not easy.
It's normal to have fights,

that doesn't mean that it's
the end of the relationship.

So instead of the
either the Disney story

or the Photoshopped
lives of celebrities,
actually real life isn't like that.

And sometimes you've got
to get your head down
and you've got to work at it.

Appreciation and not becoming
complacent is so important,

at the end of the day it doesn't
matter if you've been together

for a few years
or you've been married for thirty,

the fact that that person's
choosing to be with you is massive.

So always appreciate them
and their presence in your life
and all that they bring to it.

And the more you appreciate
them and show it
the more they'll do for you.

Well you're very intelligent,
incredibly determined.
You're just, um...

You're just like... I dunno.
I just like hanging out with you.
She's just a very
kind, nice, generous person.

You should write these things
on Post-It notes
and just leave them around the house.

Put them on the mirror
for you in the morning.

Whilst positive relationships are
really important for our health,

negative relationships are
really bad for our health.

So it's so important to know when
to draw the line and walk away.

Now it may be that one of you
wants to work on the relationship

and the other one doesn't,
and if one of you is motivated

but both of you are not
it's not going to work.

On the other hand
if you're in a mentally

or physically abusive
relationship for example,
then you have to own your own worth

and know that you deserve
so much better than that.

You have to be able to walk away
to protect your own mental health

and wellbeing, not just now
but in your future as well.
